Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports students at U.S. institutions to attend the 4th Networking Networking Women (N^2Women) Workshop. This workshop will be co-足located with the 2014 annual conference of the ACM Special Interest Group on Data Communication (SIGCOMM 2014), to be held in Chicago, Illinois, August 2014. The workshop will be a full-day event held on the Sunday preceding the main conference in order to foster connections between attendees early in the week. Moreover, we have selected the Sunday timeslot to avoid conflicts with the technical workshops associated with the conference, which will be held on the Monday preceding the conference. Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending the workshop, but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. Students attending the N^2Women Workshop will be encouraged to stay and attend SIGCOMM.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this proposal resides in the contributions that the student participants will make to (1) the N^2Women Workshop, (2) the SIGCOMM 2014 event (the premier conference in the networking communications field) and (3) the future scientific progress of the students? research. The exposure to the technical content of both the N^2Women Workshop and SIGCOMM 2014 will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective field, with a long-足term benefit of scientific progress for these types of networks.

Broader Impacts: The broader impact of this proposal is the development of the under-足represented graduate students who with this t ravel support are able to attend the N^2Women. The travel funds will allow these graduate students to attend high-足caliber technical presentations, be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students. We expect the impact to the students? careers from attending the N^2Women Workshop to be substantial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported nine female researchers in the area of computing networking to attend the fourth Networking Networking Women (N^2Women) workshop and the annual SIGCOMM Conference, the top conference in the field of computer networking. The N^2Women Workshop provides a collegial atmosphere and fosters discussion among participants from the industrial, governmental, and academic sectors. Seventy-seven researchers registered for the workshop, of which nearly 80% were junior researchers. The workshop included two keynote talks and two panels featuring top researchers in the field of computer networking; two small-group mentoring sessions; and a student poster session where 21 students presented their work and received feedback from the community.

A post-workshop survey conducted by the CRA-W yielded 29 responses from participants and five responses from speakers and panelists. All 29 respondents rated the workshop as a whole as good or excellent. Over 96% of responses indicated somewhat or very much satisfaction with the mix of speakers at the workshop, and over 91% of respondents indicated that they achieved what they hoped to achieve at the workshop either somewhat or very much. Comments about the workshop included the following:  “I think the workshops were VERY helpful in putting things (questions in my mind) into perspective.” and “Wonderful experience!! I really enjoyed the workshop.” All presenters said the workshop was a satisfying experience and they also all reported that they would definitely recommend that colleagues or students participate in a similar workshop. Overall, our survey shows that 93% of participants indicated that the workshop increased their confidence that they can have a successful research career in this area by a little or a lot.
